title: SPA Performance Paradox
context: Teams choose Single Page Applications (React, Angular, Vue) for 'better user experience.' The SPA loads a large JavaScript bundle upfront, then handles navigation client-side without full page reloads. The transitions feel smooth — after the initial load. But that initial load is the problem. Users on slow connections or older devices stare at a blank screen for 3-5 seconds while megabytes of JavaScript download, parse, and execute. The SPA optimized for the developer's MacBook Pro, not the user's $200 Android phone on 3G.
hypothesis: Single Page Applications provide better user experience than server-rendered pages.

chain.root: Build application as a Single Page Application

children.label: Large JS bundle must download, parse, and execute before anything renders
Users on slow connections see blank screen or loading spinner for seconds
Every 100ms of load time costs 1% of conversions

effects.label: SEO suffers without server-side rendering
effects.impact: Client-rendered content invisible to many crawlers

children.label: Google can render JS but other search engines and social crawlers can't
Teams add SSR/SSG to fix SEO — negating the SPA simplicity argument
Hydration adds complexity and can cause layout shifts
Screen readers struggle with client-side routing and dynamic content
Browser back/forward behavior requires manual reimplementation
Deep linking, bookmarking, and sharing require explicit handling

effects.label: Complexity shifts from server to client
effects.impact: State management, routing, caching all reimplemented in JS

children.label: Client-side state management (Redux, Zustand) adds significant complexity
API layer required for every data interaction
Bundle size grows with every feature — performance degrades over time

dontIf: Your application is primarily content-focused (blog, docs, marketing, e-commerce)
Your users are on mobile devices with variable connection quality
SEO is important for your business
ifYouMust: Use SSR or SSG for initial page loads — hydrate to SPA after
Set strict bundle size budgets and enforce them in CI
Code-split aggressively — load only what's needed for the current route
Test on real devices with throttled connections, not just your dev machine

alternatives.name: Server-rendered with islands
alternatives.note: Astro, Fresh — static HTML with interactive islands where needed. Best of both worlds.

alternatives.name: Progressive enhancement
alternatives.note: HTML-first, enhance with JS — works without JS, better with it

alternatives.name: HTMX / server-driven UI
alternatives.note: Server renders HTML fragments, client swaps them in — SPA-like UX without the JS bundle

seo.description: SPAs ship 200KB-2MB of JavaScript, pushing First Contentful Paint to 2-5 seconds. Mobile bounce rates increase 30-50%. The 'better UX' optimizes for the developer's MacBook, not the user's phone.
